items.title: I hope I word this okay.
items.content_html:
And I hope it doesn’t come off sounding like I’m unappreciative of the work that goes into Tiny Theme. I am very appreciative of it, and in fact, I reveal the attribution to the creator within the footer of my microblog, along with references to my customization.

However, today, while adding a new head.html template override in order to add a <meta name="color-scheme" content="light dark"> for passing through to an <iframe> also using the same meta tag, I discovered that the Tiny Theme head.html adds a <link rel="author" href="humans.txt"> which functions to say that the author of the current document is what is in that humans.txt. That is, the creator of Tiny Theme.

While it is true that the theme was authored by this person, the current document was not. I do not think this is the appropriate use of the rel="author" attribute, either via link or meta tags. I’d venture to guess most people don’t realize that is there.

From MDN:

author

Indicates the referenced document provides further information about the author of the current document or article. Relevant for <link>, <a>, and <area> elements.

With <a> and <area>, it indicates the linked document (or mailto:) provides information about the author of the nearest <article> ancestor if there is one, otherwise the entire document.

With <link>, it represents the author of the entire document.

Update: I filed an issue on the repo: Usage of link rel=author in head.html

And I hope it doesn't come off sounding like I'm unappreciative of the work that goes into Tiny Theme. I am very appreciative of it, and in fact, I reveal the attribution to the creator within the footer of my microblog, along with references to my customization.

<!--more-->

However, today, while adding a new `head.html` template override in order to add a `<meta name="color-scheme" content="light dark">` for passing through to an `<iframe>` also using the same meta tag, I discovered that the Tiny Theme `head.html` adds a `<link rel="author" href="humans.txt">` which functions to say that the author of the current document is what is in that `humans.txt`. That is, the creator of Tiny Theme.

While it is true that the *theme* was authored by this person, the *current document* was not. I do not think this is the appropriate use of the `rel="author"` attribute, either via `link` or `meta` tags. I'd venture to guess most people don't realize that is there.

From [MDN](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Attributes/rel#author):

> `author`
> 
> Indicates the referenced document provides further information about the author of the current document or article. Relevant for `<link>`, `<a>`, and `<area>` elements.
>
> With `<a>` and `<area>`, it indicates the linked document (or mailto:) provides information about the author of the nearest `<article>` ancestor if there is one, otherwise the entire document.
>
> With `<link>`, it represents the author of the entire document.

--- 

**Update:** I filed an issue on the repo: [Usage of link rel=author in head.html](https://github.com/MattSLangford/Tiny-Theme-for-Micro.blog/issues/12)

I want an opt-out that is enforceable. The idea that the “open web” ever meant that publicly accessible information was freely up for grabs for consumption by for-profit companies is incredibly discouraging from someone who proselytizes IndieWeb principles.

@paulrobertlloyd I see it a little differently. I’d like to see more effort by AI companies to credit sources, so that the balance between crawling and publishing is closer to what we have with search engines. AI companies are not going to go away, but we need to push them in the right directions.

‚Äî Manton Reece

Also, to believe that something can “never go away” or that anything lasts forever, along the lines of “too big to fail,” is simply rolling over and accepting waves of authoritarian bullying.

I am starting to find it untenable to remain on a platform that seems to be embracing this ethos. Especially when they simultaneously feel the need to place blame on someone asking for another person to be accountable for their words and actions that harmed someone with less power than them. It is not surprising when you think about these two scenarios being nearly the same thing: when a power dynamic is not in balance and support is given to side already with more power.

items.title: üå± Garden Status (2024/06/15)
items.content_html:
We are five days from the summer solstice. Today’s sunset was at 9:01pm and next Thursday will be the latest sunset of the year at 9:02pm. I read today that the summer solstice in Portland is 6 hours and 59 minutes of daylight longer than the winter solstice. Nearly a whole new day of light within a single day. I’m exhausted just thinking about it. I love what summer does to the garden, but I do get weary this time of year and dream just a little bit of a cooler and darker existence, when the rains come.

This update includes some random shots from the garden this morning. The back sun loving perennial border is coming into full bloom now. Finally, the Shasta daisies are opening, the two I have are double and full of frills. This buttery yellow one is so smooth and creamy I could plant it everywhere and not get tired of it. We had some rain today and the centers gathered the rainfall and a fly was taking a drink, I could not decide on a favorite so you get all three.

Along the top of the rockery, and to be honest through the rockery, the blue star creeper is…creeping. This plant is a thug and I have to tear bunches of it out every year but I just cannot tear it out completely. Not only because it would be so hard but because look at it, it creates this mounding cascade of blue pillows this time of year and is usually covered in bees. Please note: this was one four-inch nursery container when I planted it üëÄ‚Äîwatch out!

The back perennial border is mostly full of sun loving plants that flower from now until fall, with the exception of the far west corner that falls into shade against the west fence in the afternoon. But the vista of flower colors and foliage is always lovely and calming in the morning when they all see sun together.

A single container update, as this is turning into my favorite combination so far, purple + orange. I’ve been calling this begonia orange creamsicle though I know that is not what it is called. The purple flower is a Jamesbrittenia hybrid and is performing far better than I imagined it would in its mostly shady location on the patio. Love the color of the flowers with orange center playing off the orange of the begonia. Gorgeous.

items.title: On Accountability
items.content_html:
We had a bit of drama in an overlapping of two communities I am part of a couple weeks ago. I think it went by mostly unnoticed by the folks who were not affected or who did not involve themselves in the commenting/replies.

This post by Mandy today touches on something I think is important. Though the entire post is more about accountability in the sense of roles or positions at a job, she explains something about it that is absolutely relevant to how several people responded to what happened in our communities.

If you‚Äôve ever participated in a blameless post-mortem, you‚Äôve already experienced that model of accountability. In a post-mortem, the aim is to unearth what happened‚Äîthe story‚Äîwithout passing judgment on or retaliating against any of the characters within it. The explicit freedom from retribution is what makes it possible for people to speak openly and honestly of an event. If I can speak candidly about how I fucked up, knowing no harm will come to me, I am more able to admit my mistakes, learn from them, and commit to making whatever repairs may be necessary to recover from the harm. Paradoxically, it‚Äôs the lack of blame that creates the possibilities of repair and insight, while the threat of punishment forecloses opportunities for both.

I think the key line here is: “The explicit freedom from retribution is what makes it possible for people to speak openly and honestly of an event.” And unfortunately that did not happen in this case, because almost immediately “one side” started to call people names and act like a victim. The person on the other side who attempted to start a conversation and “speak candidly about how [someone] fucked up” was then made out to be the bad guy. So all good intentions and good will was out the door at that point.

At this point I’m not entirely sure how this could have been made better. But Mandy’s framing of accountability from an old definition of “to render an account” is a good place to start. How can we put our pitchforks down have rational discussions through stories? In fact, the actual harmed person did just that on their own blog, and they were still further attacked by the other side. It was rather shameful and I’m sorry to have both witnessed the drama and for the person harmed. We can all do better by listening and learning before we speak or take action.

items.title: I started 100 Days to Offload challenge today.
items.content_html:
These first few days will sort of be figuring out how I want to do this on 100daysof.blog. I’ve started taking daily notes in the MB Notes feature. This may end up being a daily log. That might work well for this type of challenge, especially if I can pull off a 100-day streak. It’ll definitely be all about posting the mundane day-to-day bits.

In the process I changed from the default Marfa theme to Alpine in order to shrink the header a bit. I don’t want to be caught up in theming or styling on this blog because I’d like to remain concentrated on the purpose: posting 100 times in the next year, ideally before the end of 2024, or even in the next 100 days.

This inevitably led me to need to tweak some things. Nothing huge but I ended up discovering that both Marfa and Alpine are styling some things based on an HTML id and that that id is being used on multiple elements in the document. This seems pretty basic to me as invalid HTML so I’m sure it is an oversight.

I headed over to the Github repo for the Alpine theme but issues do not appear to be active, so I instead posted this as an issue on the Micro.blog help center. Hopefully that is the right place to put it. If I wanted to spend more time on it I could have fixed the issue myself but as I was saying, I purposefully am trying to avoid that with this blog. There will be plenty more opportunity for custom theming when I get started on Table for One Cafe.

items.title: Working on answering some interview questions today.
items.content_html:
Not a job, something else. I’ll be publishing the answers to my weblog for posterity just like I did my XOXOFest answers though I did not submit those. These answers will be submitted to the interviewee.

I’m glad I’ve taken so much time to flesh out my weblog in terms of pages (slash pages!) because they hold such a wealth of information about me that I will be able to refer to many of them to help me finish this task. I find that every time I have a thought or something I want to document about myself I always want it on my weblog.

It feels so important nowadays to own this stuff and not give it to someone else who won’t respect its value and won’t hesitate to throw it away or sell it off when it is convenient. I don’t mourn the demise of some parts of capitalism, such as big platforms. It only makes more clear the necessity of the spaces we curate and treasure for ourselves.

I only publish posts to the timeline that use the category timeline because sometimes I don’t want every post to hit the timeline. So now no posts are hitting the timeline.

Today I also noticed that, despite my recent complaint, the Discover timeline continues to be a circle jerk of guys. It is 100% guys this morning. I’m told it is in a transitional period, and that despite “our best intentions” it reflects the overall make-up of the Micro.blog userbase: guys.

You build community with intention, folks. Community, real community, does not happen by mistake or because you miraculously hit a sweet spot of hive minded individuals. That’s not community. That’s a cult. That’s a hobby you spend two hours doing on the weekend with people you don’t discuss the politics of your identity with because you might “hurt someone’s feelings.”

IT IS NOT HARD NOT TO BE A DICK. It is not hard to find interesting posts by interesting people who do not look and think like you. Discover, if I am not mistaken, is meant to be a place to discover new people that other people might be interested in following or finding new and different content to read. Discover is not your timeline or what you are interested in reading or following.

Please step out of your sheltered life and try just a little bit to see other people unlike yourself, especially male and white. By curating a timeline that looks like this you are not only harming those already here, but you are showing people not here who might be considering joining, what your values are. And if I wasn’t already here I don’t think I’d be joining today based on the values I’ve recently witnessed.

items.title: üå± Garden Status (2024/06/01)
items.content_html:
This garden status is exclusively about patio containers. I recently swapped out the pansies and violas for my summer combos after loading up at the garden center this week. It has been a few days so the annuals have settled in and a few have started blooming. I’m even seeing foliage growth in just the two days since they’ve been in the containers. Annuals are pretty amazing that way.

So think about these pictures as a “before” state. I have two experiments going on: I’m relying on marigolds in the containers flanking either end of the patio, the ones that get more sun on the east and west ends. This will be interesting to see if it is enough sun for the marigolds to perform. I’ve also planted some Jamesbrittenia (hybrid) in two containers that get either morning or afternoon sun for a couple hours. Very questionable whether it will be enough, so another test.

items.title: Some Day Notes (2024/05/31)
items.content_html:
Holy crap, it’s been a minute! Many things have happened and much time has passed. I am tired and preparing for a long relaxing weekend on the heels of WeblogPoMo 2024, but I realize I’ve attempted to start a note for about a week and failed each time. It is now or never, let’s do this!

We left off last time during the April Micro.blog photo challenge, I’ll pick up where the last note ended.

  • I finished out the April photo challenge, and in retrospect feel it to be a sweet sad thing as it may have been the last Micro.blog event with Jean at the helm, as she bids the team farewell to pursue other endeavors.
  • At the end of April, my neighbor’s tree fell on my garage and set off a series of brain draining events. I dumped my thoughts into posts:
    • Stream of consciousness from Discord on a tree falling onto my garage.
    • A complicated üîÜ Little bright spot
    • Today I have to meet with the roofer…
  • In the aftermath of the tree falling, I was a bit of a mess.
    • I have uploaded the last two Micro.blog photoblogging challenge…
    • I am feeling overwhelmed and unprepared…
    • Guilt and Loathing in Portland
  • I wrote more about my plans for WeblogPoMo 2024 and how they went:
    • Tiny pages and not-so-tiny pages.
    • What are Tiny Pages?
    • Wrapping WeblogPoMo 2024
  • As a nearly permanent fixture in my life, and as May was ME/CFS Awareness Month, I wrote a bit about illness:
    • It never stops.
    • Even disability professionals get it wrong.
    • I love how COVID aware people are…
    • On this International ME/CFS Awareness Day…
    • The Sick Times: Ten new books about Long Covid, chronic illness, and disability
  • Every month the AI fever pitch gets more shrill and I respond:
    • There is no ethical use of AI in a climate crisis.
    • I’ve had this thought but never put it into words.
    • AI for dummies.
  • I wrote about a sudden and unexpected event regarding my student loan: An education, if you can pay for it.
  • I shared some quotes from recent streaming television shows I’ve been watching:
    • Acapulco is far more funny than I expected.
    • “Elsbeth” S1:E8 dialogue
  • A while back I polled Mastodon on how often folks redesign their sites and I finally wrote something up about that: How often do you redesign your site?
  • May is the best gardening month, in my opinion. I shared a lot of my garden and visited another lovely garden:
    • Garden Status (2024/05/06)
    • üå± Garden Status (2024/05/15)
    • Visited a rhododendron garden today.
    • üå± Just a couple shots of the back garden this morning…
    • I went to the garden center yesterday.
  • I took a look at weblog stats and wrote about the most popular posts: Weblog Top Posts
  • I shared a family recipe: Fresh Fruit Cobbler
  • Protests on college campuses have been skewed by those with power, and PSU in Portland is no exception: ‚ÄúThe book stacks seem pretty untouched,‚Äù…
  • I wrote about things I’ve been learning:
    • CSS Color Modules and Changes, Part I
    • Improvements to citations with footnotes and endnotes.
  • I spun the blogroll twice:
    • Blogroll Spin #5
    • Blogroll Spin #6
  • In pursuit of creating a favorites page, I wrote a three part series:
    • Favorites, Part I
    • Favorites, Part II
    • Favorites, Part III
  • A less complicated üîÜ Little bright spot
  • I joined the chorus in writing about My computer origin story.
  • I attended my first Micro.camp & followed up by writing about community and some things that have been bothering me about Micro.blog and other communities:
    • Cooking while I watch Micro Camp today…
    • A Community of Concerns
    • So I guess now it‚Äôs cool to deride…
    • I guess I‚Äôm just unwilling to budge…
    • Discover recently has been 9/10 guys…
  • I wrote about Adding a ShareOpenly link to weblog posts.
  • I added a fourth part to a series I started during NaBloPoMo 2023: Working for a Living When Your Living isn’t Working, Part IV
  • I loathed bad men:
    • Sometimes I wonder if there is like…
    • Not all ‚ÄúMen in suits sat around a long table.‚Äù…
  • I read about slash pages, created some slash pages, and a slashes page to keep track of them:
    • It’s my blog and I’ll cry if I want to.
    • A Slashes page for my slash pages.
    • A Roadmap and Changelog
    • Brag for yourself.
  • I lamented the end of XOXO and having never gone: XOXO 2024: The first time with longing!
  • Red Lobster filed for bankruptcy and I had something to say about that: Companies are made of and for people.
  • I saw birds: The house finches have a great interest…
  • I belatedly weighed in on the “man or bear” debate by sharing a post I read and a quote from another streaming television show I was watching:
    • Man or Bear: one woman’s perspective
    • The perfect quote to follow up…
  • I dealt with family drama and wrote about it: This is not the post you are looking for.
  • It was a month of too much: Today…

I think that is all I can fit into this post and this month. I’m sorry it was so long since the last one so likewise this ended up being a very long note. If you made it this far, you are very dedicated. See you next time and have a wonderful weekend!

items.title: I went to the garden center yesterday.
items.content_html:
After clearing out the pansies and violas that had been in my patio container since last October, I needed summer annuals and a few other garden products. I ended up spending $200 which hit me hard at the time. First, I’m unemployed and chronically ill and every dollar I spend needs to be considered. Second, it seemed like a lot.

It got me thinking about many of the YouTube gardening channels I frequent and how many viewers respond or comment about the amount of money the channel owners spend on plants and infrastructure. I did a little math this morning and the plants themselves cost $130 of the $200, thirty-two plants at roughly $4 a piece (very simplified math). Many of the YouTubers respond to these comments on growing your own annuals from seed to save money, but this is also simplified math.

First of all, most people are already short on time. Accumulating the tools and infrastructure for growing things from seed is also an up-front cost that only pays off if you continue to do it every year. It also isn’t really valuable in terms of time spent if you’re only growing three dozen plants. Another way to save would be to propagate some of the plants at the end of the season and overwinter them indoors. Things like begonia and coleus propagate easily and can be quite happy house plants. But that also takes time and house plants can suffer from pests and disease.

As someone with an energy-limiting chronic illness, my time and energy is just as valuable to me as my money. If I were to view this as a trade-off between what I could charge as an hourly rate as a web developer, I’d only be able to spend about an hour to an hour and a half caring for seedlings or propagations over the winter months to see the benefit. That is frankly unrealistic. I’ve come out of this endeavor now feeling like the money was well spent. There’s no shame in buying your annuals if the cost-benefit to grow your own does not work in your favor.

I’ll be planting the patio containers up this afternoon or tomorrow, so of course I’ll share some pictures when I’m done!

items.title: Man or Bear: one woman's perspective
items.content_html:
What I find the most striking in this piece is her description of sizing up the risk with a million calculations on the spot. This is what many of us have to do to survive under patriarchy on a daily basis, but hearing it described by someone alone in the backcountry makes me really sad.

It could be something he says. Maybe he makes a comment about my body or my appearance. Or he asks if I‚Äôm carrying a weapon and then presses for details about where I‚Äôm camping that night. Sometimes, it‚Äôs a shift in his tone, a leer, the way he puts his body in my space. But, usually, it‚Äôs a combination of things, a totality of behaviors that add up to a singular reality: this man is either not aware that he‚Äôs making me uncomfortable, or he doesn‚Äôt care. Either way, this is the danger zone. Even if he has no intention of harming me, the outcome of that intention is no longer possible for me to assess or predict.

In this moment, my mind snaps into a single, crystalline point of focus. My intuition rises to the surface of my skin. I become a creature of exquisite perception. The world is a matrix of emotional data: visceral, clear, direct.

I need to get away from the man. But I need to do it in a way that doesn‚Äôt anger him. This is the tricky bit. Men who lack social awareness or empathy often also lack other skills in emotional management. And usually, what men in these situations actually want is closeness. They‚Äôre trying to get closer to me, physically or emotionally, in the only way they know how. That combination of poor emotional skillsets and a desire to get closer is exactly what puts me in danger.

items.title: The Sick Times: Ten new books about Long Covid, chronic illness, and disability
items.content_html:
I’ll be looking these up on Libby for Multnomah County Library, but expect: a) a long wait, or b) no availability. I’d love to see a disabled/chronic illness book sharing program, where you could become a member to share costs for physical copies and then ship them back and forth based on a calendar. It probably wouldn’t scale well, but might be useful for a small group of readers.

  1. Pillow Writers Anthology 1: Near-Life Experiences (self-published, 2024)
  2. Illness Politics and Hashtag Activism, By Lisa Diedrich (University of Minnesota Press, 2024)
  3. Moving Mountains: Writing Nature through Illness and Disability, Edited by Louise Kenward (Footnote Press, 2023)
  4. In it for the Long Haul: A Long Covid Journey, by Jon Douglas (self-published, 2024)
  5. Disability Intimacy: Essays on Love, Care, and Desire, by Alice Wong (Vintage Books, 2024)
  6. The Long Covid Reader, Edited by Mary Ladd (Long Hauler Publishing, 2023)
  7. Tilt, by Morgan Stephens (Aldrich Press, 2024)
  8. Move That Cloud, by Dylan‚Äôs Dad (Grow By Reading LLC, 2024)
  9. Do ‚ÄúSomething‚Äù: My Attempt at Nutritional Therapy to Minimize Long-Covid Symptoms (aka the Only Place I‚Äôm Running is Out of Hope), by Vicky Gilpin (Invictus Phoenix Publishing, 2024)
  10. Viral Underclass: The Human Toll When Inequality and Disease Collide, By Steven W. Thrasher (Celadon, 2022)

items.content_html:
Good morning from the sun and one of my favorite views in the backyard: the inside curve of the berm.

We are in for another fairly warm day, though hopefully cooler than the last two (86¬∞-90¬∞F depending on your location in the metro). Though I am enjoying the increased sun on this area in the morning with the neighbor’s tree gone, it is a woodland/shaded part of the garden falling under the magnolia tree and I far prefer the dappled shade and shadows during the rest of the day.

Plants in this view, from bottom to top:

  • part of ‘Seaview Sunset’ rhododendron, no longer blooming
  • a dwarf false solomon’s seal ground cover
  • a dwarf hosta
  • a dwarf fern
  • Pacific bleeding heart
  • a hellebore, no longer blooming
  • three heucheras, a dark red-purple leaved one, a light peach-red leaved one, and a dwarf green-leaved one
  • a dianthus, not yet blooming
  • a dwarf geranium, not blooming, barely visible in this picture
  • a sword fern
  • the magnolia tree trunk
  • three azaleas, (mostly) no longer blooming
  • the bottom of a weeping white spruce
  • ‘Czechmark Trilogy’ weigela in the back corner, blooming

The modern tech company or capitalistic enterprise is taking cues from fascism and dictators in how they introduce a small piece of controversy, like a testing of the waters. Wait for an “overreaction” by the masses/their audience/core users, wait for that to burnout and normalize, before flooding the zone with too much to fight or argue with all at once. This is the same way fascism causes burnout and complacency and feelings of helplessness, like there’s nothing to be done to fight the thing.

This is what is being done with AI.

items.title: Garden Status (2024/05/06)
items.content_html:
This garden status may be a little premature, but I figure I’d better get it in before the upcoming “heatwave.” We had a very pleasant April, but it was fairly dry, though not overly warm, just…pleasant. This may seem great but it meant that our normally wet spring hasn’t really been so wet. Over the last week, the rain has returned and many of the “May flowers” are sitting with buds-in-waiting for some sunshine so they can do their thing.

It is currently Monday, May 6, 2024, and our forecast high in Portland is to be 57¬∞F. We’ve had gray skies, rain, sun breaks, downpours, hail, and blue skies and sun, all just today. By Friday that high temperature will be 88¬∞F and many things in the garden, having just been doused with two inches of rain, will explode with the sudden temperature increase. Many other things that have had a prolonged and beautiful bloom this spring will begin to fade.

I just made a round in the garden and took some photos. Some things are not quite ready for prime time, I expect I will need to make an interim “garden status” post in a week or two to include some of the plants that really would like to be blooming already but are not.

In the meantime, here are some things I found lovely today and in the past week.

It is currently Monday, May 6, 2024, and our forecast high in Portland is to be 57¬∞F. We've had gray skies, rain, sun breaks, downpours, hail, and blue skies and sun, all just today. By Friday that high temperature will be 88¬∞F and many things in the garden, having just been doused with two inches of rain, will explode with the sudden temperature increase. Many other things that have had a prolonged and beautiful bloom this spring will begin to fade. I just made a round in the garden and took some photos. Some things are not quite ready for prime time, I expect I will need to make an interim "garden status" post in a week or two to include some of the plants that really would like to be blooming already but are not. In the meantime, here are some things I found lovely today and in the past week.

items.title: Even disability professionals get it wrong.
items.content_html:
From the bookmarked article below, a quote that sums up so much of what society gets wrong about disability. To me, I think it is a fundamental misapplication of the prefix “dis-” which means “opposite of.” But in words like “disfunction” the application is not “does not function” it is that it isn’t functioning as expected or as desired. In my opinion, this should be the application of “dis-” in disability as well. Sometimes that simply means that the conditions are not met to create ability through no personal fault, often due to environmental or societal factors knowingly or unknowingly not creating the conditions for ability.

It was very common for disability professionals to frame disability as related to either inability or ability ‚Äì focusing on what people cannot or can do. Many of these professionals thought that disabled people were discriminated against because of their inability to achieve things. This is problematic because it assumes that disabled people are lower in ability. It also assumes disability is all about if a person can achieve something. This is not only not true, it also individualizes disability, blaming the person for their situation, ignoring the many barriers that are placed in people‚Äôs ways.

items.title: It never stops.
items.content_html:
My teenage years were pretty traumatic between finding out about having this terrible illness, being psychologized by doctors, and abandoned by friends and family, and treated terribly by my schools. And that was more than 30 years ago.

This was a story that found me. In 2021, after writing about long Covid, I was accused by the psychiatrist Prof Michael Sharpe of spreading it. Apparently, you could induce such illnesses by discussing them. Investigating further, I was astonished by the failure in his presentation to support his claim with evidence, and perturbed by his lack of satisfactory answers to my questions. Sharpe takes a similarly ‚Äúbiopsychosocial‚Äù approach to ME/CFS, one which at the time of his long Covid presentation still dominated medical practice in the UK.

You can trace the origins of this model to a paper published in 1970. Without assessing a single patient or interviewing a single doctor, it blamed an earlier outbreak of post-viral ME/CFS on ‚Äúmass hysteria‚Äù based on case notes alone. The reasoning included the fact that the outbreak affected more women than men. For centuries, doctors have been readier to classify women‚Äôs illnesses as ‚Äúhysterical‚Äù or psychosomatic than they have men‚Äôs. ME/CFS, like long Covid, hits women harder, so, the thinking goes, it must be all in the mind.

We now know that patients were right to resist interventions that have proved to be both useless and harmful. The impacts were often horrific. A study in Switzerland found that the most powerful factor contributing to suicidal thoughts among people with ME/CFS was ‚Äúbeing told the disease was only psychosomatic‚Äù.

Some patients were forced into these treatment regimes, even locked in psychiatric units to make them comply. Some parents of children with ME/CFS were referred to social services for supposedly encouraging their belief that they were ill. Though unevidenced, the biopsychosocial model influenced the government‚Äôs social security policy, reinforcing its coercive treatment of people seeking disability benefits.

items.title: üîÜ Little bright spot
items.content_html:
Today’s little bright spot is complicated.

Yesterday morning, before I’d even made coffee or gotten out of my robe, I heard cracking. The sound of wood doing something it shouldn’t. At first I looked outside in the direction I thought it was coming from and didn’t see anything unusual. Or so I thought. We had a bunch of rain the day before and my neighbor’s apricot tree, freshly laden with leaves, did appear to be hanging a bit low in front of the garage, but not too low.

But the cracking continued. And the tree was falling. All day. Lower and lower. I went outside to try to assess what was going to happen with it, since the direct path of the fall was my garage. I had a pile of mulch in front of the garage, leftover from moving it around my yard, but directly in the way of getting the car out of the garage.

So, there in my robe, having had no coffee, I shoved half the mulch pile into the wheelbarrow and over to the side of the driveway, enough so that I could get the car out of the garage, a) before something terrible happened, or b) the tree branches blocked me from doing so. I managed to do both things still in my robe.

After that I concentrated on calling people: my neighbor, who I had not heard from and who I don’t think was home, my homeowners insurance, unsure if I’d need to make a claim, and several other neighbors to talk about the circumstances. The circumstances as they were that that tree should have come out ten years ago. I’ve hated it since I bought this house. And apparently the neighbor knew it needed to come out and had had the tree service over a week ago to start the removal process.

In Portland if you want to do anything with a tree, you need a permit. Unless you are planting one on private property. But if you are removing one, you need a permit. If you are planting one in a right-of-way like the parking strip, you need a permit. It’s a system that has lofty goals but rarely works to achieve those goals and most people hate the system. First of all, it is slow. Painfully slow.

So while the neighbor was waiting on a permit the tree went ahead and fell on my garage. Now, I don’t know that they knew it was in danger of falling, but I do know that three days ago I was clearing the gutter on that side of the garage in preparation for the rain on Thursday, and I kept hitting my head on a branch that didn’t used to be there so I suspect my neighbor knew something was happening and that the tree was already leaning. I did not recall this hitting-of-my-head until this morning when I was talking with the arborist.

But let’s talk a little bit more about this tree. It is an apricot tree, and a very large old apricot tree, most likely planted back when this neighborhood used be full of empty lots and many vegetable gardens and fruit trees. My yard likely had a fruit tree too. And that house was built in the 50s the same time my garage was built, so it is likely that that apricot tree was in an empty lot. My house was built almost 100 years ago.

Apricot trees, like many stone fruit trees, like warm dry weather, they are not suited to Portland’s climate for the most part. And that tree was never happy. Every spring it would barely bloom as we’d get a late cold snap, and then it would try to leaf out only to be hit with a long wet spring and sporadically drop leaves, sprout more leaves, and drop leaves again. It would try to fruit, but it never succeeded, instead it dropped sappy orange goo onto my garage roof which would then dry and stick to the shingle’s texture and rip it off. Then to top it all off, every fall it would drop all its leaves nearly at once, covering the entire east side of my garage roof, gutter, and the narrow space between the garage and neighbor’s fence. So many leaves, so stinky, that it could fill my green compost bin three or four times.

I hate(d) that tree.

The neighbor was going to remove that tree. They had started the process of doing that and were planning on footing the bill. But as soon as the tree fell and endangered my property, I became responsible for part of it. This is bullshit. I looked high and low for the reasoning that I could tell them they needed to pay for the entire removal without luck. It is viewed as “storm damage” and if it hadn’t damaged my garage would not even be covered by my insurance. Even with my insurance coverage I’d still have to pay my $1000 deductible. I didn’t know if the cost of all the removal + damage would even exceed that.

Friday proved fruitless (heh üòè) in getting an arborist to come out, but my neighbor was able to get the arborist that was going to remove the tree and that was waiting on the city for a permit to come out today, Saturday. In the meantime the tree dug in, so to speak, piercing my garage roof, denting my gutter, and falling lower and lower in front of the garage door. I was under the impression that my garage was holding the entire weight of that tree for 24 hours.

The arborist was very kind. He was actually the owner of a very popular tree service in Portland and did all the removal of the portion on my side himself, from the top of the roof. Another crew member hauled the branches away down my driveway. I ended up paying for the hourly service of two crew members, quoted $600-700 though I have yet to be invoiced. I imagine the bulk of the tree and trunk removal to be quite a bit more than that on my neighbors side, but again, it is their tree and they were planning on removing it anyway. I am bit perturbed by this fact and that they didn’t offer to cover the entire cost. It is frankly a bitch move and not very neighborly.

We ended up being very lucky. The damage to the garage is minimal in the end: two roof shingles and a dented gutter; my neighbor’s fence has some snapped off slats but it was in need of repair anyway. Two things were working in our favor: on my neighbor’s side a 2x4 piece of lumber in part of their kid’s play set was holding up part of the tree’s weight; on my side, a 4x4 concrete-filled steel post used by a gate (overkill much?) was holding up another part of the tree’s weight. It could have been far worse. But I’m still under the deductible so I’m footing all of this work and damage.

So, you are asking, how is this a little bright spot, Anne? I’m doing a lot of complaining.

Well, what if I told you someone came to me months ago and said: for roughly $600 we will remove that tree that you hate so much? You will never have to clean its mess up again and an abundance of light would flood into your backyard making you able to possibly grow vegetables again! Yes! I would absolutely do that! I would pay $600 to never deal with that tree again!

Moving here for posterity.

  • my neighbor’s tree has fall on my garage

  • I’ve hated that tree for ten years

  • and this is its revenge on me

  • the funnest part of all of this? getting to decide who pays! so far my insurance says it is my neighbor’s liability and my neighbor says the tree company says I have to pay!

  • and all of this could have been prevented if I didn’t live in Portland where you have to get a permit to remove a tree, something that apparently my neighbor was already in the process of, and now the tree has gone ahead and fallen down while waiting on the damn city

  • so maybe the the city should pay?

  • me this morning in my robe before I even had coffee: moving a mulch pile so I coud back a car out of the garage in case the damage got worse

  • that little car has the best turning radius, I managed to squeak it out of the garage and along the house with just about an inch or two of space to spare, I had to get out of the passenger side door

  • the tree is still falling, every once in a while I hear another crack

  • and apparently there are zero tree crews on a Friday so nothing can be done about this until tomorrow

  • I feel like I’m living in a world where nothing makes sense

items.content_html:
It is high time for another note! I’ve made it under a month this time, such an accomplishment. I particularly feel like I need to get this done now, before April ends and May begins, because I will be busy in May, and I’ll explain a bit about that at the end of this note.

The last three weeks have seen me in the garden a lot. I’ve had tasks to complete and the rest of the mulch to spread and I’m back on a weekly mowing schedule, so it is definitely The Season again. I’ve also been busy with more web projects and tinkering and am about to jump into another one in May, though a couple of them are just sitting on the back burner for now while I am occupied by other things.

So let’s get into it!

  • On the same day I posted my last note, I published What I’ve learned about CSS color-scheme and friends. and was surprised and delighted by the positive reactions to it. Nothing is a better cure for imposter syndrome than writing something slightly technical and getting good feedback from a mostly technical audience. I really love this “format” of writing: diving into a topic, making a tangible example/use case, and blogging about it‚ÄîI would do nothing but this if I could!
  • I am continuing the April photo blogging challenge on Micro.blog and doing better this time with not beating myself up over diving into my photo library for many of the pictures. I’ve taken some new ones, but 80% of the entries are probably from the archive.
  • I’m trying to be better about writing more openly about the different parts of me. Owning your content is owning yourself.
  • On the heals of buying tableforone.cafe I wrote about one of the ideas I have for it: My grandmother’s recipe box.
  • A Garden Status (2024/04/11) post, which is a series I’m trying to keep up on, if not intermittently. This is the time of year for it, though it might be nice to continue with it year round because the garden never truly sleeps.
  • Blogroll Spin #4 is in the books and with it more omg.lol members join the list üòÖ
  • My long-awaited Weblog Publishing Workflow is finally finished and published. This took so long to do and caused me a lot of anguish, partly because I didn’t want to miss anything and partly because it is a bit of exposure into how I’m doing things unconventionally and I didn’t want to be judged. But we can’t get through life without being judged so I pulled off the bandage and bared my wounds! Really, it turned out pretty great, and I’ve gotten lovely feedback on it as well. Thanks to all those who have told me they liked it! I think my takeaway from the experience and feedback is that there truly is no right way to get your content onto the web and that is really part of the beauty of it üíú
  • 100th weblog post! Fittingly, the Weblog Publishing Workflow post was my 100th weblog post. Thinking about getting all these posts into the last ~15 months has made me eye a goal: completing the 100 Days To Offload blogging challenge some time in the next year! And that had me acquiring another new domain: 100daysof.blog which will also be a Micro.blog blog. Both this and tableforone.cafe are sitting idle because I have too many things going on at once right now (why do we do this to ourselves?)
  • I read and listened to many chronic illness and health-related things:
    • This could be a big deal for people like me…
    • It is impossible to read this and square it with…
    • Put a hold on this book on Libby…
  • I’ve been using a web component on my weblog (and wrote about it in February) for embedding a Mastodon post, retrieving interactions for the post, and prompting more interaction. The author of that component recently created another that I’m now using on my microblog, in combination with EchoFeed, and I’m really liking how it is working out. Adding link previews to echoes on my microblog.
  • Of course I had some AI-related opinions:
    • The “publicly on the web” excuse for AI is malarkey.
    • Your AI isn’t making my life better.
    • It’s just the same boring playbook…
    • This period is the great dumbing down.
  • On the tails of my color-scheme post, and in pursuit of extending this knowledge and usefulness, I pursued an idea I had been toying with and which I saw some discussion of on Mastodon. I’m starting with themes.lol using color-mix() with the accent-color used on some form controls with system colors to get a “hue” in both light and dark modes. I’m still working on this, and want to implement it elsewhere, but will definitely have a post on it at some point, likely during the upcoming blogging challenge.
  • I wrote some more about my garden: I have a yard. No, I have a garden.
  • And more: The gentians are in their prime.
  • And even more: Here is the result of my hard work this week.
  • We all need a üîÜ Little bright spot.
  • Finally, the biggest news of this note: WeblogPoMo 2024! This will occupy my time and concentration for the month of May so that is why many other projects may sit idle or see very little progress for at least another month. But I do foresee some of the things I’ll be blogging about making their way into already active projects, such as themes.lol and even weblog proper.
  • I expand a bit on this new blogging challenge in a post: WeblogPoMo 2024 and tiny pages.
  • I purchased yet another omg.lol address, üçè, and with it I plan to set up my “tiny pages” to use for CSS experiments during WeblogPoMo.
  • JS Naked Day (today) made me have thoughts: Excuse me while I beleaguer a point.

That is probably all for now. As WeblogPoMo will absorb all my brain resources for the next month, I may not have a new note until it ends. Have a great week and see you in June!

items.title: Excuse me while I beleaguer a point.
items.content_html:
We are entering JS Naked Day! We just got through CSS Naked Day a week or so ago! These are great days, and I think the point of them might be getting lost…or at least the point I always got from them: here’s how a site looks, works, and breaks without some of the tools of the web.

It is not only a way to show how well your site works without these tools, but as a cautious tale of how your site breaks without these tools and to provide a lesson perhaps to yourself and others! I want to see these things and I want them to provide guidance on what to do better.

The scramble to perfect the flaws in the days leading up to the so-called Naked Days I think masks the lessons we should be learning. What if instead we bared these imperfections and wrote about it? Maybe put up a caveat on your home page saying “look, I can do better, maybe you can too” because this might be one day for you and me, but some people for one reason or another experience the web every day without these tools.

I hope I don’t sound like I’m preaching from an ivory tower, as I did not participate in either this year, though I do plan to in the future. I absolutely appreciate those who do, even when they scramble to fix bugs. But I’d also love to see what we’ve taken for granted and how we can work to make the web better through these little revelatory exposures.

items.title: This period is the great dumbing down.
items.content_html:
I’ve been thinking about how to frame this time period we are in. A time after a great wave of illness. Indeed we are still in that great wave, even if you aren’t hearing about it from your government or on the news. This is step one.

And then with step two we have this “magic tool” that has been sold to so many as a panacea of knowledge, a way to level the field. Except its effect will have the exact opposite result. It will not level the field but increase disparity.

It won’t replace menial jobs, it won’t create high quality, high paying, high reward employment for folks. No, menial jobs will only increase, and with them the need to work more of them. Hard and unforgiving jobs. Jobs that make you scrape the barrel.

And that is step three. When your needs aren’t met, you can’t think critically. You don’t see big pictures, you see what is in front of you to get you to whatever is the next thing.

items.title: Here is the result of my hard work this week.
items.content_html:
And why I am pretty much laid up today. Two years ago, I removed the grass behind the berm from just beyond where it ended near the new basalt rock pathway from the sideyard to the patio. That was such a success that I decided to finish removing the remaining strip this year to round out the lawn in the backyard and be completely rid of narrow grass paths.

This section proved much harder the strip behind the berm, I think due to the proximity to trees and roots. I removed the sod in four strips, two strips a day for two days. And then on the third day I had my neighbor bring me a few wheelbarrows of top soil the he’d removed from his front yard to put in some drains and rock paths. It was a perfect situation. Finally, I topped the soil with four wheelbarrows of mulch and tamped it down. This turned out exactly as I had hoped it would, and now the path from the grass and around the berm in what I call “the woodland” is complete.

In a lot of ways this is the continuation of that project I started two years ago, after the completion of a basalt stepping stone path in the sideyard. I don’t publish to Substack anymore, but you can read about that project here: Behind the Berm.

This turned out exactly as I had hoped it would, and now the path from the grass and around the berm in what I call "the woodland" is complete. In a lot of ways this is the continuation of that project I started two years ago, after the completion of a basalt stepping stone path in the sideyard. I don't publish to Substack anymore, but you can read about that project here: [Behind the Berm](https://anniegreens.substack.com/p/behind-the-berm). --- POSSE copies:

items.title: I have a yard. No, I have a garden.
items.content_html:
You might notice I talk or post about it a bit. I share photos. I am proud of my garden. Every single plant in it I put there. What used to be empty terraces in the front and lawn all around, is now a mature and varied garden with interesting microclimates and “rooms”. This took thought, patience, and dedication.

Gardens need places for the eye to rest. Moments of silence in the physical landscape. Sometimes this takes shape with a lawn. People hate lawns because they use water and chemicals. But lawns still provide a purpose and if used in moderation I still feel have their place in the garden.

In my garden there are only two small areas of lawn remaining. I removed all of the rest of the lawn, approximately 2/3rds of the total lawn that used to make up my yard is now landscaped garden beds designed by me. But that remaining lawn does require irrigation. Had there not already been lawn and irrigation here when I bought this house, it is likely there never would have been.

In the city of Portland you are required to maintain an irrigation system. This might or might not mean you hire someone to do that. But at a minimum someone licensed to do so must perform a backflow test, and this usually coincides with the spring startup of the system. For me this occurred on Tuesday this week, and I had the guy perform a couple tweaks to my system.

One of those tweaks was to the controller. Six or so years ago I had a weather system put in that is connected to my irrigation controller. It is just a little device that collects rain water and tips it out when it gets to a certain point, takes temperature readings, etc. and stores all of that data in the controller and tells it when the different zones of my garden need water.

I have four zones, only two of them are lawn, the two areas mentioned above. The remaining two are drip for some of the newer areas of garden beds where I provide drip emitters directly to a plant’s roots. Now you may be wondering why I am telling this backstory about my yard, garden, irrigation, lawn, etc. Here’s why.

My neighborhood has a “healthy” raccoon population. I’ve witnessed entire families traveling through my yard. I’ve seen momma’s with five kits scaling a fence. I’ve see a momma with a single kit in the middle of the day! But mostly I see the aftermath of raccoons in my yard. And of that aftermath is what happens during the summer when it is hot and the irrigation runs late at night/in the middle of the night and the raccoons decide to have a party.

It is not a pretty sight. It is a mess. They damage plants, they dig holes, they cause mayhem. Last year when the irrigation guy came out I asked them to change the controller to run the irrigation in the morning not at night because of the raccoons. I watched the guy get into the controller and seemingly perform the modifications for this request. However, it was not really fixed. I attempted again, I had tried before, to navigate this controllers settings and menus, and alas dear reader, this system is too complicated for me, an unusual thing to admit.

So last year I got up every day during the summer that I ran the irrigation (not every day) at 5am and manually ran it to avoid the Rowdy Raccoon Rave in the garden. I did this for four long months, basically May-September. It wasn’t fun, but I didn’t feel like calling the irrigation guy back, which would have incurred a charge and I just wasn’t in the mood to tell this guy that he did his job wrong.

This year it was a different guy and he fully admitted the controller is far more complicated than it needs to be, that even he had a hard time figuring it out, and that he tried to make the changes but was unsure, and that if I have issues or it isn’t running when I want it to to call him back. He even said he might have to send his supervisor to figure the controller out. I have to tell you I feel so much better about myself after that conversation. And last night, well, this morning, guess what? The system ran at the right time! I was making coffee and it started at 5:15am just like he said it would! I am elated, you don’t understand, this is so great.

items.title: Today's featured photo from the Photos app (2024/04/14)
items.content_html:
This tree is yet another of my Japanese Maple survivors. I started a draft on Substack when I was still writing there in 2022 about my other survivor and never finished it. Maybe I should move it here.

I nearly killed this tree last year when I took a hose from the driveway to water it. The hose had been laying on the concrete all morning and picked up solar gain, superheating the water inside. I wasn’t thinking and almost immediately realized what I had done but it was too late.

Over the course of the next few days to weeks, the tree lost nearly all its leaves, but later pushed out new growth into the summer. I didn’t know what was truly dead so I waited for it to bud out this spring and pruned off everything that had no signs of growth. I lost about half the canopy. But it lived. It has the most spectacular fall color.

April 14, 2024

items.title: Garden Status (2024/04/11)
items.content_html:
It has been about a month, maybe a little less, since the last Garden Status and we’re getting into the thick of spring. Everything is popping! I grabbed some photos this week, so here’s a slew!

There are three aubrietas in the front yard terraces and next to retaining walls that are as lovely as can be this year. The candy tuft (not pictured) is also more full of blooms than I can remember in years past. My neighbor tells me these plants really like a good long vernal period and we haven’t been having those much in recent years (probably due to climate change), but this year’s deep intense 14-15¬∞F freeze in January must have done the trick for them.

There is no end to the joy the pansies, violas, and primroses, bring me each fall/winter/spring. If my climate allowed, I’d grow them all year. But in about a month, the temperatures will not longer be conducive to them thriving and I’ll be swapping them out for heat-loving summer annuals. Enjoy them while you can!

The Deshojo Japanes Maple tree on the patio is fantastic this year. It’s had a rough couple years, and I considered it being time to move it out of the container and into the ground. Unfortunately this would not happen in my garden because: a) I don’t have the room for another tree in my garden, and b) I have had a Japanese maple succumb to Verticillium wilt in my garden, and other than the two Bloodgoods in the parking strip, which are quite mature and not showing any signs yet, I don’t want to take the chance on any others. I lost a Crimson Queen and it crushed me. So, when this tree needs to get out of its container, it will leave my garden and end up elsewhere.

This tree will transition the leaves to all-green by summer time, and then back to a rainbow of hues and brilliant reds and oranges in the fall. This bright pinky-red color only lasts for a brief fleeting moment in the spring. It really is one of the best Japanese maples for color changing leaves.

The common name of this plant is “bog rosemary” but it isn’t a rosemary, and it isn’t even closely related to rosemary. Bog rosemary is more closely related to ericaceous evergreen shrubs such as huckleberry, blueberry, and cranberry. The name comes from the rosemary-esque leaves, though upon closer inspection they resemble tiny rhododendron leaves, also a relative, and its tolerance and preference for boggy growing conditions‚Äîdon’t let it dry out!

I don’t often post pictures of the weeping white spruce (Picea Glauca ‘Pendula’) because it is sandwiched between two other trees and hard to get on its own. It usually is included in more expansive pictures of my entire backyard. But this year the tree is producing cones! Little red cones, oodles of them at the top of the tree, though I see signs of them farther down, so I’ll need to get some pictures of them too once they develop. I got up on a ladder to get these pictures üòÅ

And the final set of pictures are of a narrow upright crabapple in the back corner of my yard called ‘Marilee’. This sweet little tree produces the most adorable bright pink buds followed by classic pinky-white apple blossoms with yellow starburst centers. And they cover the branches in what appear like sleeves of blossoms.

items.title: Some Day Notes (2024/04/06)
items.content_html:
A month has gone by since my last note‚Äîwhere did the time go?! Much of it has been spent struggling internally over how to spend my time: web tinkering or gardening. Since spring is well upon us in western Oregon, I have a lot to do on both fronts.

We avoided a late freeze this year so the magnolia tree has been in one of the most abundant and log-lasting blooms (super bloom?) of any year since I planted it more than ten years ago. Over the past week I’ve been mulching the garden, a little bit at a time. I’m about 2/3rds done, but most of the work will be in the backyard where I need to rake up some magnolia petals in the rockery before spreading mulch and I’ll be removing some sod in the back corner of the garden to round out the lawn. I’m planning on using some of the sod to fill a few holes elsewhere.

On the web, I am keeping up a good cadence with blog posts, both here on Micro.blog and on weblog. I’m still working on themes.lol regularly and keeping the homepage set to show the most recent updates. On 3x5.pics a new index card is published every four days. I purchased a new domain (tableforone.cafe) and plan to use a second microblog and custom theme for it. But first, I want to get an initial release of my styles on themes.lol wrapped.

Enough of the preamble, onward!

  • I’ve carried on with my featured photos but noted a change to how I curate them in a post.
  • I wrote a small response to a piece published by NPR regarding continued vigilance by chronically ill and vulnerable folks.
  • We got an awesome new feature on Micro.blog to create a blogroll (“recommendations”) and I had a reaction to the makeup of a lot of what I was seeing, both here and other places.
  • I made a soup!
  • I published a “case study” (in quotes as I hadn’t necessarily considered it that way until it was featured in Roma’s fantastic CSS bookmarks and called that) on creating 3x5.pics where I go more into the technical decisions of the design.
  • On weblog, I made a “featured post” component.
  • We hit a milestone with the pandemic (yes, it is ongoing) and my featured photo that day included some reminiscing.
  • The aforementioned magnolia super bloom.
  • I started another series on garden status, where I plan to give frequent updates with photos on how my garden is doing throughout the seasons and years. This might include projects and may eventually morph into resuming my newsletter‚Äîwe shall see!
  • I joined the IndieWeb webring on this microblog, the first I’ve joined here. I have several on weblog, and I’d like to join more!
  • The blogroll on weblog took its third spin and I included information about incorporating my microblog into this ritual.
  • I’m still thinking about cross-posting, I still haven’t set anything up. I think I will have better momentum on this soon.
  • I discovered thehtml.review.
  • I tried to keep up with my Little bright spot series.

A month has gone by since [my last note](https://micro.anniegreens.lol/2024/03/09/some-day-notes.html)‚Äîwhere did the time go?! Much of it has been spent struggling internally over how to spend my time: web tinkering or gardening. Since spring is well upon us in western Oregon, I have a lot to do on both fronts.

<!--more-->

We avoided a late freeze this year so the magnolia tree has been in one of the most abundant and log-lasting blooms (super bloom?) of any year since I planted it more than ten years ago. Over the past week I've been mulching the garden, a little bit at a time. I'm about 2/3rds done, but most of the work will be in the backyard where I need to rake up some magnolia petals in the rockery before spreading mulch and I'll be removing some sod in the back corner of the garden to round out the lawn. I'm planning on using some of the sod to fill a few holes elsewhere.

On the web, I am keeping up a good cadence with blog posts, both here on Micro.blog and on weblog. I'm still working on [themes.lol](https://themes.lol) regularly and keeping the homepage set to show the most recent updates. On [3x5.pics](https://3x5.pics) a new index card is published every four days. I purchased a new domain (tableforone.cafe) and plan to use a second microblog and custom theme for it. But first, I want to get an initial release of my styles on themes.lol wrapped.

items.title: I am on a quest for an answer.
items.content_html:
I’m prepared not to get one. I’m prepared not to be satisfied by the ones that I get. But I’ve been bothered by this thing long enough now I’m asking it.

If you share photos anywhere: on Mastodon/Pixelfed/etc, on your own website, on some other public platform where other people have access to it, and you don’t add alt text for images, why?

I really cannot understand the lack of empathy behind it. I’ve heard every manner of excuse, including the sometimes draining effects for people with cognitive or other limiting factors from writing the text. I actually have those factors. Part of my illness is cognitive limitations and I have to be mindful of them when I decide to take something on. If I don’t think I can complete the thing with the necessary requirements, I don’t undertake the thing. That includes posting a photo. I will put it off if I can’t add alt text for other people who also have limiting factors.

My consternation at the lack of alt text I encounter day-to-day is most disturbing when it is done by someone who absolutely knows better: an author who writes about typography! It is such a jolt to witness, a dichotomy that makes me never want to purchase anything he creates. I find it so sad and bizarre and I can’t come up with a meaning other than apathy.

If you have another reason, I’d love to hear it. If you try to add alt text but sometimes forget or fail, I’d love to know. I need some faith in humanity restored here.

items.content_html:
This will supplement my Manual of Me, but mostly I just want to get all this praise in a place I own and off of LinkedIn. And re-reading several of these from when I left my last job is sort of making me tear up a little bit. The people I worked with were so great, it was the “job” that was crap.

Still to this day, my most favorite developer in the world is a guy named Mike V., shucks I miss him. We were on three projects in a row and could communicate without even talking. LOL

He was a man of few words, if you know the kind. But he wrote me an email at the end that was full of words and told me I taught him a lot about front-end and design systems. Totally a back-end/infra type of developer, so that was some major kindness.

I wonder where those emails got put…I think I exported stuff to somewhere.

items.title: I can't fall asleep so I'm awake and listening to Pandora.
items.content_html:
Specifically, my Tycho Radio station, a station that I began curating in 2009 when I first subscribed to Pandora. This station is so thoroughly me that there is never a song I don’t approve. It’s frankly shocking. But besides that, every song evokes something I can’t quite describe.

Because the station has been with me for so long I feel movement when I listen to it. It is like longing, but also yearning. It feels like a personal station of songs just for me. I think a lot the songs surface memories from all the times I’ve heard them. I know this happens to a lot of people with albums. But of course there are multiple artists and multiple albums.

The station was created right after a painful break with a boyfriend that sort of tore me apart. So there was a lot of finding myself involved in this station. One of the best songs that is representative of the station is Ti√´sto Ten Seconds Before Sunrise. The station begs a new beginning and makes me want to try.

items.title: I'm doing it again.
items.content_html:
I’m posting long rambling thoughts on spaces other than my own. What a hard habit to break.

Olu writes really good stuff on behavior in the digital age, and this most recent question is so interesting to me.

Especially her follow up, where she says almost her entire dating life has been online. I would say it is an age thing, but I don’t think it is. Maybe it is personality or life experience, but I would say my dating experience is the literal opposite, I’ve never taken online dating seriously. This might be a trust thing on my part.

Anyway, you should answer her if you have opinions!

Someone else follows up saying something about algorithms, and yes, that’s one of my issues.

This is a weird comparison, but I feel very similarly about online dating as I do about weight loss programs. At one of my first jobs, Jenny Craig was a client. At my last company, Weight Watchers was a client. So I’ve see things.

items.title: My ME Life: my last job (part one)
items.content_html:
Since the first actual post in this series, “some early childhood”, my brain went to my last job. So, I’m obviously jumping around quite a bit. I think there are several reasons for this. Nothing is a straight line, and most definitely not in my life. I think some parts of my life have had larger influences on the whole, and then of course there are contemporary events that make me think back to certain periods. My last job is one of them, as I’m still reeling from that time period.

I was working at what was supposed to be my dream job. I had left the job prior to that feeling dissatisfied and taken for granted. During my annual review I came prepared with my accomplishments, strengths, and plans for the next year, coupled with demands for a merit/salary increase. While they agreed to the first part of the equation, they did not agree to the second. So, I went packing and applied like a “cold call” to a place that I had always admired, a place I thought of as a pinnacle in the open source community I was a part of.

When I put in my notice at the other place, guess what happened? Yeah, they offered me the salary I had asked for. Too late, my dream job offered me a 12% increase over that! But as with most things you place on a pedestal, they rarely live up to the ideals you imagined, and my dream job ended spectacularly. Over the years, and especially in the immediate aftermath, I thought I should write a book about the experience. I guess whatever I write here will have to serve as that now.

It was Labor Day weekend and we all got notice to be in the office by 9am the following week for an important announcement. This email came in during the holiday weekend, if I recall correctly. It may have actually made reference to a “big new project”. The big new project? The business was shuttering. But what happened when we returned to the office from the weekend went even further.

Not only was the business shuttering, but the middle management had known about this for some time and were doing all they could to save us, the workers, from having to scramble to find jobs on short notice, and, possibly worse, compete with each other applying to similar places. The work we did on the platform we used could very well end up that way. But I think how it actually went may have added insult to injury.

We were faced with what I can only describe as a panel of executives. If that makes you want to cry, well, yes, I did some crying later that day. For all of the “oh shit” feelings this dug up in me, having left a job only a year earlier after feeling unappreciated and then only after threatening to leave was told “yeah, sure we’ll pay you what you think you are worth”, this was bringing up a lot of bad feelings. I had come to this company with stars in my eyes, a company whose tagline was “Technology for Good” and I’d spent a year working on a new platform for AmeriCorps VISTA.

This panel of executives was from a company based in Washington, DC, and they worked on giant platforms (using the same software we did) but it was anything but technology for good. Even before acquiring the dream job, this company had opened an office in Portland and garnered a reputation for paying high salaries but expecting workers to trash their work/life balance. I felt cornered, to put it mildly. The panel was there for the week, and they would be interviewing us all as an on-the-spot job application, so to speak. No, I’m not joking. The next day I came in and was put into a small room with two guys, one I sort of knew from the tech meetup scene, and the other one was one of the owners of the company from DC.

The interview left me feeling all the things: imposter syndrome, like all my eggs were in this one basket, was I stuck in some contract that prevented me from looking elsewhere? Of course, you could choose not to apply and just finish out the month at our current company, as that is what the arrangement was: the current company would shutter at the end of September. You would interview with the new company, and if approved for a position, would spend that month “working” for them on a contract basis. Then we would all find out at the beginning of October if we had permanent full-time positions with them. It was hell. I felt like I was living on pins and needles for a month. It was like an ouf-of-body experience. I had to put feelers out there and see what other positions were viable lest I find myself hanging without a hope in a month.

And I did that, but I didn’t actually end up finding an alternative. What I did do was build up a repository of information to come armed with if and when they gave me a job offer. I was surprised that it paid off and they gave me the salary I asked for. I took the job with the new company from DC and would be starting in their brand new office in The Pearl along with the fourteen other team members that were also coming on board, plus their existing staff that had been previously crammed into a tiny “coat closet of an office” in SE Portland, as well as anyone else from the company from across the country that would be moving to join us.

To be continued.

items.title: I'm taking a small media break.
items.content_html:
I don’t know what this looks like yet, but I’ve been really upset with some of the conversations around Threads and the Fediverse. I need to organize my head, internalize some of the discussion, and really just keep to myself and finish writing some blog posts and pages I really want to finish. I’m tired of feeling upset about it.

I do not envy what many Mastodon admins are grappling with right now. One of my favorite people on the internet, Adam of omg.lol, is a Mastodon admin on social.lol and watching him internally (and externally) feel tortured by this has upset me. But I’m also upset just generally from how it is all playing out and what it reveals about people and society.

I’m upset enough by my situation in life right now. How society has already placed constraints on my freedom and ability to thrive while a very real threat in virus form continues to circulate and cause disease, death, and disability. Another realism people just don’t want to deal with.

So, I’m stepping back in little bits. I will write my words in my own spaces. But I need some distance from all the conversations that are upsetting me “out there”. I don’t feel like I’m making progress in finding a medium of agreement and I don’t have the energy with the day-to-day of my illness to continue to get upset.

Take care of yourselves, and each other. Have empathy and be as kind as you can. You don’t know everyone’s circumstances.

items.title: Garden Status (2024/03/18)
items.content_html:
I have a spate of photos from the garden this week due to our mini early Spring rain reprieve and abundant sunshine. The rain will return on Wednesday, but since about last Thursday we’ve had consistent high 60s to mid-70s degree F. I was lucky with the magnolia this year as we did not get hit with a late cold snap in February and bud production went unhindered.

One of the best years on record for magnolia blooms, though perhaps a little hastened from the recent warm days. I’ll still take it, far better than waiting a full year just to have the first 1/3 or blooms turn black and shrivel up from a desiccating and frigid east wind or ice event.

I’ve been sporadically posting photos here (via Featured Photo category) and on my gardening-centric Mastodon account, but after snapping a few shots outside this morning decided to upload a nice group to Flickr and share a first-of-kind Garden Status post! I haven’t made this a category, not sure I will, but I’ll tag it for series to it can at least be marked as that.

I think the remainder of this post will just be images‚Äîenjoy!

items.title: I made a fantastic soup yesterday.
items.content_html:
I had something in mind, I searched for a recipe to work from (just to get some type of proportions right), and then threw in what I had on hand.

It is a ditalini vegetable soup with:

  • 1 onion, chopped
  • 1 very large carrot, chopped
  • about 1 1/2 celery stalks, chopped
  • 4-5 garlic cloves, finely chopped
  • 1/4 cup olive oil
  • 1 15-oz can cannellini beans, drained/rinsed
  • 1 28-oz can whole tomatoes, with sauce (do not drain)‚Äîcrush in pot with masher/back of wooden spoon
  • 1 large head of broccoli, cut into small florets
  • 1 package frozen peas
  • 6-8 cups vegetable stock (I used half water, you could probably use all water)
  • 1/2 package ditalini pasta (about 1/2 pound)
  • a combination of, I didn’t measure, but about 1/2 to 1 teaspoon each:
    • Italian seasoning
    • dried parsley
    • dried basil
    • dried thyme
    • bay leaf
    • red pepper flakes
    • kosher salt (to taste)
    • freshly ground black pepper (to taste)

I think that is it…I might have missed something, I’ll add it here if I remember anything more. You could add zucchini, baby spinach, brussels sprouts, it’s a pretty versatile base. Substitute the cannellini for chickpeas or other canned bean. You could leave out the pasta entirely, though it does help thicken it up, perhaps try pearled barley instead (will take extra time to cook, might need to add it in with the liquid at the 30-minute simmer step).

Basically, sweat the first four ingredients with the olive oil, then add the rest, except for the ditalini. Cover and simmer for 30 minutes or so. Add ditalini and continue to cook about eight more minutes. Turn off burner and let sit for another 20 minutes. Serve with fresh grated parmesan.

items.title: I'm not going to name any names.
items.content_html:
Perhaps especially on the IndieWeb there is a pretty heavy bias on male (and white) perspectives. I’m seeing this in who is included in some popular email newsletters when there are equal and earlier published representations of the same content by non-male authors, and also in who is being included in blogrolls.

I can’t say I’m not disappointed even if I’m not shocked. I am an aware female in this world, I live every day so this is unfortunately par for the course.

I will say that this is exactly why I chose to spin my blogroll. I wanted to be conscientious of who gets added, when they’re added, and what the make-up of the set is at the time I add it. Of course, this takes time and thought and that’s a lot more effort than some may want to put into it. I also wanted to include blogs that are new to me and that contain content outside of my usual circle.

The IndieWeb deserves better. We all deserve better. Broaden your horizons, folks. It is 2024 and you know what type of forces are out there on the rise. You can easily fight back against it by raising voices different than your own.

items.title: A response to that ableist NPR piece today.
items.content_html:
I barely made it through the first two paragraphs. I definitely didn’t give it any more attention than that because I knew what it centered: an ableist attitude that prevails in media and politics right now and shuts out so many disabled and chronically ill people from every day life.

NPR‚Äôs decision to platform a piece about the difficulty of navigating life with a spouse who can‚Äôt dine indoors, instead of a piece about the difficulty of navigating a society that has made dining indoors unsafe for vulnerable groups, is just that- a decision, and a political one. It is part of an ongoing effort to cast those who cannot play along with the ‚Äúback to normal‚Äù fantasy- those who are being harmed and killed by it- as weird, paranoid, crazy, annoying, and ‚Äúthe problem.‚Äù

‚Äî Disabled people’s exclusion from indoor spaces is a civil rights violation, not an annoyance

I shouldn’t link to it, but I suppose I have to for context: Wrestling with my husband’s fear of getting COVID again

items.title: The Featured Photos is evolving.
items.content_html:
In the beginning of this adventure, it really was a daily featured photo that the Photo app on my iPad chose. But that has become less reliable and more redundant. I find myself seeking out photos that I am reminded of or if something unrelated has me looking back through time and I happen upon an image I want to use.

As mentioned recently, I am now compiling a list in Notes, a more curated list. This may mean I choose several images from the same trip. It might just mean a few of them are from the same year as I’ve seen them closely together while scrolling through my Library. Either way, it is less random and more intentional.

Perhaps this is meaningless to you. Just know that they are no longer chosen by an algorithm in an app.
